newsitem.title: REPUBLIC OF IRELAND: PRESS DIGEST - Ireland - November 11.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Ireland - November 11.

text.p: Following are the highlights of stories reported in the Irish press on Monday.
- A second high-profile Irish government minister, Education Minister Niamh Bhreathnach, is facing calls for her resignation as problems continue to pile up for the coalition parties.
- One prison officer was stabbed and a second jabbed with a blood-filled syringe during an attempted escape as a prisoner ran amok in a Dublin hospital on Sunday.
- The name of an Irish judge who retired earlier this year is still listed on the panel eligible to sit in the Special Criminal Court.
- Ireland's Finance Minister Ruairi Quinn will on Monday try to broker a deal on detailed preparations for the EU single currency set to start on January 1, 1999.
- Almost 1,400 new jobs in the electronics sector will be announced this week.

- The Social Democratic and Labour Party (SDLP) on Sunday let its leadership decide on the question of a possible electoral pact with Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, in advance of next year's British general elections.
- It has been suggested that Northern Ireland police officers involved in the Orange Order, the Freemasons and the Ancient Order of Hibernians should list their involvement in a public register.
